topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic struct-d) (topic firmware-d) (topic pmcrevhis-d)
topic.title: Crosslink

body.p: Switchtec ports support the optional crosslink capability specified in PCI Express Base 4.0 Specification. As per the specification, a crosslink is formed when a Downstream Port is connected to a Downstream Port or an Upstream Port is connected to an Upstream Port.
An NT crosslink is formed when an NT EP is connected to an NT EP via a USP to USP connection.

fig.title: Crosslink connecting two host domains (NT Crosslink)

body.p: Crosslink is enabled by default and defined in PCI Express Base 4.0 Specification. Switchtec ports are capable of establishing crosslink with any link partner, including another Switchtec port. When crosslink is formed between two ports, the physical layer of one of the ports operates as an upstream component (e.g., downstream lanes) while the physical layer of the other port operates as a downstream component (e.g., upstream lanes). The determination of which of the two ports that form the crosslink operates with upstream or downstream lanes depends on the link training process as defined in the PCIe specification.

section.title: Hot Reset Handling
section.p: Hot reset is not supported on a crosslink as the unique characteristics of a crosslink (being USP to USP or DSP to DSP) puts it outside the scope of a hierarchical reset propagation scheme.

section.title: Hot Reset Handling (Internal)
section.p: When a Switchtec port forms a crosslink, the hot reset operation is dependent on whether the port is operating in either upstream or downstream switch port mode.

For a port operating in upstream switch port mode, the physical layer responds to the reception of training sets only when the hot reset bit is set by a transition to the hot reset state. There is no mechanism in the higher layer to place the port in the hot reset state. This behavior of the upstream switch port mode will occur regardless of the physical layer mode of operation (i.e., upstream or downstream lanes).

For a port operating in downstream switch port mode, the physical layer responds to the reception of training sets when the hot reset bit is set by a transition to the hot reset state. The hot reset will not reset the configuration registers of the port nor will it affect other ports in the partition. If a higher layer directs the port to a hot reset (i.e., partition hot reset, upstream secondary hot or downstream secondary hot reset), the physical layer will enter into the recovery state and proceed to the hot reset state. This behavior of the downstream switch port mode will occur regardless of the physical layer mode of operation (i.e., upstream or downstream lanes).

section.title: Link Disable Handling
section.p: Crosslinks cannot be disabled via normal PCI configuration space due to their unique nature. They can be disabled via MRPC (see Switch Management).

section.title: Link Disable Handling (Internal)
section.p: When a Switchtec port forms a crosslink, link disable operation is dependent on whether the port is operating in either upstream or downstream switch port mode.

For a port operating in upstream switch port mode, the physical layer responds to the reception of training sets only when the disable bit is set by a transition to the disabled state. There is no mechanism in the higher layer to place the port in the disabled state except when the port is NT EP only mode and NT crosslink enable.Direct write link disable bit can make port in the disabled state in this situation.This behavior of the upstream switch port mode will occur regardless of the physical layer mode of operation (i.e., upstream or downstream lanes).

For a port operating in downstream switch port mode, the physical layer responds to the reception of training sets when the disable bit is set by a transition to the disabled state. If a higher layer directs the port to disable the link, the physical layer will enter into the recovery state and proceed to the disabled state. This behavior of the downstream switch port mode will occur regardless of the physical layer mode of operation (i.e., upstream or downstream lanes)

section.title: Disabling Crosslink
section.p: Crosslink can be disabled by resetting the CFG_CROSSLINK_SUPPORTED bit in the port’s TL Bypass Configuration Register 3. When a Switchtec upstream port is crosslinked to a link-partner’s upstream port, neither port may automatically initiate a link speed change to Gen 2 or Gen 3, thereby resulting in a Gen 1 link. It is possible to overcome this by setting CFG_HW_AUTO_SPEED field in Gen 2 or Gen 3 and enabling CFG_HW_AUTO_SPEED_REQUEST in the Switchtec upstream port’s TL Bypass Configuration Register 2. By setting this field, the Switchtec upstream port will initiate the link transition to Gen 2 or Gen 3 speed.

section.title: Crosslink-to-Self
section.p: Switchtec ports support crosslink-to-self (i.e., transmit lanes to receive lanes of same port) using a proprietary built-in mechanism in the LTSSM. This mode must be explicitly enabled for each port by setting the Self Crosslink Enable (MGMT_TLB_DEBUG_SELF_CROSSLINK_ENABLE) bit in the port’s MGMT_TLB_DEBUG_SELF_CROSSLINK register and also requires an external loopback of port Tx to port Rx.

li.p: This mode is only for debug purposes and is only typically useful for Physical layer testing.
When crosslink-to-self is enabled, it is not possible to propagate hot reset on the link or to disable the link.

ul.li: Crosslink-to-Self will train to 5GT/s or 8GT , 8GT/s or 16GT/s, according to the normal register settings, i.e. 8GT/s executes modified Equalization skipping Phase 2.
